title: Is there such a thing as absolutely nothing? - Quora

response.answer_text: There are two ways of interpreting your question: can we imagine absolute nothingness, or are there any physical examples of absolute nothingness?  The answer to the former is Yes; you have done it.  The answer to the latter is No, because "the vacuum" is full of virtual particle-antiparticle pairs popping in and out of existence.  Nature really does abhor a classical vacuum.   :-) Probably you are referring to the issue of, "What was there before the Big Bang?"  Since time came into being with the BB, it is technically meaningless to talk about "before the BB".  I know this is an assault to common sense, but common sense has been taking a beating for the last century or so!  I guess we need to cultivate "uncommon sense" to navigate the world of modern physics.

“In CTMU cosmogony, “nothingness” is informationally defined as zero constraint or pure freedom … and the apparent construction of the universe is explained as a self-restriction of this potential.” CTMU Nothingness is synonymous with “pure freedom” and “infinite density”. From the Big Bang model we can deduce an “infinite density”. Conspansion (from the CTMU) inverts the Big Bang’s expansion scenario into a model of “internal collapse”, whereby the “infinite density/pure freedom/nothingness” remains entirely static and unchanged, while the “observable universe” is the means of “pure freedom” coming to its own self-realization. Stay free.
